video.title: Maths for Programmers: Sets (Idempotent & Identity Laws)
video.description:
We're busy people who learn to code, then practice by building projects for nonprofits. Learn Full-stack JavaScript, build a portfolio, and get great references with our open source community.

Join our community at https://freecodecamp.com
Follow us on twitter: https://twitter.com/freecodecamp
Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/freecodecamp
Follow Quincy on Quora: https://www.quora.com/Quincy-Larson

topLevelComment.author: Witchmagick
topLevelComment.text:
You may need to make a correction in terminology here. Usually the definition of an identity element is an element E such that for all A in S:

E(Union)A=A
A(Union)E=A. 

This is consistent with how the empty set works when using Union as an operator, but with the way you have it when we operate with the Universe we do not get back the A (what we started with) we get back the universe:

U(Union)A=U
A(Union)U=U

So the U element does not satisfy the definition of an identity element as I have defined it, because it is not the case that for all A in S:

U(Union)A=A
A(Union)U=A

If we look at U under the Intersection operation, then it functions like an identity for that operation:

U(Intersection)A=A
A(Intersection)U=A
